definition: Formed when two rays (or line segments) share a common endpoint called the vertex
The common endpoint where two rays or line segments meet to form an angle
Any angle less than 90°. Examples: 30°, 45°, 60°, 89°
Exactly 90°. Shown with a small square symbol at the vertex. Represents perpendicular lines.
Exactly 180°. Forms a straight line.
Two angles that add up to 90°. Formula: If angle A is x°, its complement is (90° - x)
Two angles that add up to 180°. Formula: If angle A is x°, its supplement is (180° - x)
When two lines intersect, they create two pairs of opposite angles. Vertical angles are always equal.
Two angles that share a common side and vertex. On a straight line, adjacent angles are supplementary (add to 180°)
The distance around the outside of a shape. Measured in linear units (inches, feet, meters).
The amount of space inside a shape. Measured in square units (square inches, square feet, m²).
A four-sided shape with opposite sides equal and all angles 90°. Perimeter: P = 2l + 2w, Area: A = l × w
A special rectangle where all four sides are equal. Perimeter: P = 4s, Area: A = s²
A three-sided polygon. Area: A = ½bh, where b is base and h is the perpendicular height.
A round shape where all points are equidistant from the center. Circumference: C = 2πr, Area: A = πr²
The distance from the center of a circle to any point on its edge. Half of the diameter.
The distance across a circle through its center. Equal to 2 × radius.
The distance around a circle (the circle's perimeter). Formula: C = 2πr or C = πd
A four-sided shape with exactly two parallel sides called bases. Area: A = ½h(b₁ + b₂)
The bottom side of a shape, used as reference in area calculations. In triangles and trapezoids, height is measured perpendicular to the base.
The perpendicular distance from the base to the opposite vertex or side. Must form a 90° angle with the base.
At a 90-degree angle. Height must be perpendicular to the base for triangle and trapezoid area formulas.
A part or segment of a circle's circumference (edge). Arc length = (θ/360) × 2πr
A "pizza slice" region of a circle bounded by two radii and an arc. Sector area = (θ/360) × πr²
The angle formed at the center of a circle by two radii. Measured in degrees, determines the size of arc and sector.
The distance along the curved edge of an arc. Formula: arc length = (θ/360) × 2πr = (θ/360) × C
The area of a sector (pizza slice region). Formula: sector area = (θ/360) × πr² = (θ/360) × A
An arc that measures more than 180° (more than half the circle).
An arc that measures less than 180° (less than half the circle).
An arc or sector that is exactly half of a circle (180°). Arc length = πr, sector area = (πr²)/2
The steepness of a line. Formula: m = (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁) = rise/run
The y-coordinate where a line crosses the y-axis (where x = 0). In y = mx + b, it's the value b.
Linear equation format: y = mx + b, where m is slope and b is y-intercept
Linear equation format: y - y₁ = m(x - x₁), useful when you know a point and the slope
Linear equation format: Ax + By = C, where A, B, C are integers
Lines that never intersect and have the same slope. If line 1 has slope m, line 2 parallel to it also has slope m.
Lines that intersect at 90°. Their slopes are negative reciprocals: if line 1 has slope m, perpendicular line has slope -1/m.
Formula to find distance between two points: d = √[(x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)²]
Formula to find the midpoint between two points: M = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2)
The vertical change between two points (change in y). Used in slope calculation.
The horizontal change between two points (change in x). Used in slope calculation.
An equation whose graph is a straight line. General form: y = mx + b
Standard form: (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r², where (h, k) is the center and r is the radius
The point (h, k) equidistant from all points on the circle
The distance from the center to any point on the circle. Symbol: r
The distance across the circle through the center. Equal to 2r
A line segment connecting two points on a circle
A line that touches the circle at exactly one point and is perpendicular to the radius at that point
An oval-shaped curve. Equation: (x - h)²/a² + (y - k)²/b² = 1, where (h, k) is center
The longest diameter of an ellipse
The shortest diameter of an ellipse
Two special points inside an ellipse. The sum of distances from any point on the ellipse to both foci is constant.
Algebraic technique to rewrite circle equations from general form to standard form
The distance from zero on the number line. Always non-negative. Symbol: |x|
In absolute value context: |x| represents the distance of x from 0
Equation involving absolute value: |x| = a has solutions x = a and x = -a (if a ≥ 0)
Inequality with absolute values: |x| < a means -a < x < a; |x| > a means x < -a or x > a
Absolute value equations typically have two solutions (positive and negative)
The power to which a number is raised. In x^n, n is the exponent.
The number being raised to a power. In x^n, x is the base.
(x^a)^b = x^(ab). Multiply exponents when raising a power to a power.
x^a × x^b = x^(a+b). Add exponents when multiplying same bases.
x^a ÷ x^b = x^(a-b). Subtract exponents when dividing same bases.
x^(-n) = 1/x^n. Negative exponent means reciprocal.
x^0 = 1 for any x ≠ 0
√x is the number that when squared gives x. √x = x^(1/2)
∛x is the number that when cubed gives x. ∛x = x^(1/3)
An expression with a root symbol (√, ∛, etc.)
Breaking down radicals: √(ab) = √a × √b
A letter (like x, y) that represents an unknown number
The number multiplying a variable. In 5x, 5 is the coefficient.
A number without a variable. In 3x + 7, 7 is a constant.
A part of an expression separated by + or -. In 3x + 2y - 5, there are 3 terms.
Terms with the same variable and exponent. 3x and 5x are like terms.
Adding or subtracting coefficients of like terms: 3x + 5x = 8x
a(b + c) = ab + ac. Multiply the term outside by each term inside.
Rewriting an expression as a product: 6x + 9 = 3(2x + 3)
Isolating the variable on one side of the equation
Replacing a variable with a specific value
A mathematical statement comparing two expressions using <, >, ≤, or ≥
Symbol: <. Means the left side is smaller than the right side.
Symbol: >. Means the left side is larger than the right side.
Symbol: ≤. Includes the boundary value.
Symbol: ≥. Includes the boundary value.
When multiplying or dividing by a negative number, reverse the inequality sign.
Two inequalities combined: -3 < x < 5 means x > -3 AND x < 5
All values that make the inequality true
The top number in a fraction
The bottom number in a fraction
Dividing numerator and denominator by their GCF: 6/8 = 3/4
Find common denominator, then add numerators: 1/4 + 1/6 = 3/12 + 2/12 = 5/12
Multiply numerators, multiply denominators: (a/b)(c/d) = ac/bd
Multiply by the reciprocal: (a/b)÷(c/d) = (a/b)(d/c)
Flip the fraction: reciprocal of 3/4 is 4/3
Whole number + fraction: 2 1/2 = 5/2
Numerator ≥ denominator: 7/4
The inverse of exponentiation. log_b(x) = y means b^y = x
Logarithm with base e (≈2.718). Symbol: ln(x) = log_e(x)
Logarithm with base 10. Symbol: log(x) = log_10(x)
log(xy) = log(x) + log(y)
log(x/y) = log(x) - log(y)
log(x^n) = n·log(x)
A relation where each input has exactly one output. Notation: f(x)
All possible input values (x-values) for a function
All possible output values (y-values) for a function
f(x) represents the output when x is the input. f(3) means "evaluate f when x = 3"
f(g(x)) means apply g first, then apply f to the result
f^(-1) undoes what f does. If f(a) = b, then f^(-1)(b) = a
A graph is a function if any vertical line crosses it at most once
Two or more equations with the same variables
Values that satisfy all equations simultaneously
Solve one equation for a variable, substitute into the other
Add or subtract equations to eliminate a variable
System with at least one solution
System with no solution (parallel lines)
System with infinitely many solutions (same line)
Equation in form ax² + bx + c = 0 where a ≠ 0
U-shaped graph of a quadratic function
The highest or lowest point on a parabola
Where the parabola crosses the x-axis (solutions to equation)
x = (-b ± √(b²-4ac)) / (2a). Solves any quadratic equation.
b² - 4ac. Determines number of solutions: >0: two, =0: one, <0: none
Rewriting ax²+bx+c as (px+q)(rx+s) to find solutions
Method to solve quadratics by creating a perfect square trinomial
An ordered list of numbers following a pattern. Each number is called a term.
Sequence where each term differs from the previous by a constant (common difference). Example: 2, 5, 8, 11...
The constant amount added between consecutive terms in an arithmetic sequence. Symbol: d
nth term: aₙ = a₁ + (n-1)d, where a₁ is first term, n is position, d is common difference
Sequence where each term is multiplied by a constant (common ratio). Example: 3, 6, 12, 24...
The constant multiplier between consecutive terms in a geometric sequence. Symbol: r
nth term: aₙ = a₁ · r^(n-1), where a₁ is first term, r is common ratio
Formula that directly calculates the nth term without finding previous terms
Formula that defines each term based on the previous term(s)
A change to a function that shifts, stretches, or reflects its graph
f(x) + k shifts graph up k units (or down if k < 0)
f(x - h) shifts graph right h units (left if h < 0). Note the sign reversal!
a·f(x) where |a| > 1 stretches graph vertically by factor a
a·f(x) where 0 < |a| < 1 compresses graph vertically
f(bx) where 0 < |b| < 1 stretches graph horizontally
f(bx) where |b| > 1 compresses graph horizontally
-f(x) flips graph upside down
f(-x) flips graph left to right
a·f(b(x - h)) + k applies multiple transformations in order
A number greater than 1 with exactly two factors: 1 and itself. Examples: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11
A number greater than 1 with more than two factors. Examples: 4, 6, 8, 9
A number that divides evenly into another. Example: 3 is a factor of 12
The product of a number and an integer. Example: 12 is a multiple of 3
The largest factor shared by two or more numbers. GCF of 12 and 18 is 6
The smallest multiple shared by two or more numbers. LCM of 4 and 6 is 12
A number is divisible by another if division results in no remainder
Integer divisible by 2. Ends in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8
Integer not divisible by 2. Ends in 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9
Integers in order with no gaps. Example: 5, 6, 7, 8
Function in form f(x) = a·bˣ where b > 0, b ≠ 1. Example: f(x) = 2ˣ
When b > 1, function increases rapidly. Example: population growth, compound interest
When 0 < b < 1, function decreases rapidly. Example: radioactive decay, depreciation
The constant b in f(x) = a·bˣ. Determines growth (b>1) or decay (0<b<1)
The constant a in f(x) = a·bˣ. The value when x = 0: f(0) = a
The base b when b > 1. Often written as (1 + r) where r is growth rate
The base b when 0 < b < 1. Often written as (1 - r) where r is decay rate
A = P(1 + r)ᵗ where P is principal, r is rate, t is time
Time it takes for a quantity to reduce to half its initial value in exponential decay
Parts per hundred. Symbol: %. Example: 25% = 25/100 = 0.25
Put over 100 and simplify: 60% = 60/100 = 3/5
New value is original + increase. Formula: Original × (1 + rate)
New value is original - decrease. Formula: Original × (1 - rate)
Part/Whole × 100%. Example: 15 is what % of 60? → 15/60 × 100% = 25%
(New - Old)/Old × 100%. Positive = increase, negative = decrease
Comparison of two quantities. Written as a:b or a/b. Example: 3:4 or 3/4
An equation stating two ratios are equal. Example: a/b = c/d
If a/b = c/d, then ad = bc. Used to solve proportions.
A ratio with denominator of 1. Example: 60 miles/1 hour = 60 mph
The ratio of corresponding measurements in similar figures
Compares two parts. Example: boys to girls = 3:2
Compares one part to total. Example: boys to all students = 3:5
As one quantity increases, the other increases proportionally. y = kx
Changing a measurement from one unit to another. Example: feet to inches
A ratio equal to 1 used to convert units. Example: 12 inches/1 foot
Method using conversion factors to change units. Cancel units algebraically.
System using powers of 10. Units: meter, liter, gram. Prefixes: kilo-, centi-, milli-
US system. Length: inch, foot, yard, mile. Weight: ounce, pound, ton
Area units squared. Example: 1 ft² = 144 in² (12² = 144)
Volume units cubed. Example: 1 ft³ = 1728 in³ (12³ = 1728)
Form: a × 10ⁿ where 1 ≤ |a| < 10 and n is an integer. Example: 3.5 × 10⁴
The number a in a × 10ⁿ. Must be between 1 and 10 (or -1 and -10)
The power n in a × 10ⁿ. Positive for large numbers, negative for small numbers
Move decimal n places: right if n > 0, left if n < 0. Example: 4.2×10³ = 4,200
Move decimal to get coefficient 1-10, count moves for exponent
Multiply coefficients, add exponents: (a×10ᵐ)(b×10ⁿ) = (ab)×10^(m+n)
Divide coefficients, subtract exponents: (a×10ᵐ)/(b×10ⁿ) = (a/b)×10^(m-n)
Measure of likelihood an event occurs. P(event) = favorable outcomes / total outcomes
A possible result of an experiment or event
Set of all possible outcomes. Example: rolling a die = {1,2,3,4,5,6}
A set of outcomes. Example: rolling an even number = {2,4,6}
Events where one does not affect the other. P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B)
Events where one affects the other. Example: drawing cards without replacement
Event and its opposite. P(A) + P(not A) = 1
Events that cannot both occur. P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B)
Probability of two or more events occurring together or separately
Average. Sum of values divided by count. Example: mean of {2,4,6} = (2+4+6)/3 = 4
Middle value when data is ordered. For even count, average the two middle values.
Most frequent value(s) in a dataset
Difference between maximum and minimum values
A value significantly different from others in the dataset
How many times a value appears in a dataset
Collection of data values or observations
Statistics describing the middle of data: mean, median, mode
Statistics describing variability: range, standard deviation
An arrangement where order matters. Symbol: nPr = n!/(n-r)!
A selection where order does not matter. Symbol: nCr = n!/(r!(n-r)!)
Product of all positive integers up to n. Symbol: n! Example: 5! = 5×4×3×2×1 = 120
If event A has m outcomes and event B has n outcomes, together they have m×n outcomes
Items can be selected more than once. Total outcomes = nʳ
Each item can only be selected once. Use permutations or combinations.
ABC is different from BAC. Use permutations.
ABC is same as BAC. Use combinations.
A repeating or predictable arrangement of numbers, shapes, or objects
An ordered list following a rule. Example: 2, 4, 6, 8...
An individual element in a sequence
Adding/subtracting (arithmetic), multiplying/dividing (geometric), squaring, etc.
The location of a term in a sequence. First term is position 1 (or n=1)
The relationship or formula that generates the sequence
Finding the next terms by identifying and applying the rule
Pattern using shapes, colors, or spatial arrangements rather than numbers
Study of relationships between angles and sides in triangles
In right triangle: sin(θ) = opposite/hypotenuse
In right triangle: cos(θ) = adjacent/hypotenuse
In right triangle: tan(θ) = opposite/adjacent = sin(θ)/cos(θ)
Mnemonic: Sine=Opposite/Hypotenuse, Cosine=Adjacent/Hypotenuse, Tangent=Opposite/Adjacent
Circle with radius 1 centered at origin. Used to define trig functions for all angles.
sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1 for all angles θ
Two angles that sum to 90°. sin(θ) = cos(90°-θ)
Angle measure. π radians = 180°. Formula: radians = (π/180)×degrees
Number in form a + bi where a, b are real and i = √(-1)
i = √(-1). Property: i² = -1
In a + bi, the real part is a
In a + bi, the imaginary part is b (coefficient of i)
Conjugate of a + bi is a - bi. Multiply to eliminate i.
(a+bi) + (c+di) = (a+c) + (b+d)i. Add real parts, add imaginary parts.
Use FOIL and i² = -1. (a+bi)(c+di) = (ac-bd) + (ad+bc)i
|a + bi| = √(a² + b²). Distance from origin in complex plane.
A quantity with both magnitude (size) and direction. Written as <a, b> or ai + bj
Length of vector <a, b> = √(a² + b²)
The angle or orientation of the vector in space
Vector written as <x, y> where x is horizontal, y is vertical component
Vector with magnitude 1. i = <1,0>, j = <0,1>
<a,b> + <c,d> = <a+c, b+d>. Add corresponding components.
k<a,b> = <ka, kb>. Multiply each component by scalar k.
<0, 0>. Has magnitude 0 and no specific direction.
Rectangular array of numbers in rows and columns. Example: [1 2; 3 4]
Individual number in a matrix. Element aᵢⱼ is in row i, column j.
Size of matrix as rows × columns. [1 2; 3 4] is 2×2.
Add corresponding elements. Must have same dimensions.
Multiply every element by the scalar.
Row × column multiplication. (AB)ᵢⱼ = sum of (row i of A) × (column j of B)
Square matrix with 1s on diagonal, 0s elsewhere. Acts like "1" for matrices.
Matrix with all elements equal to 0.
Strategy of plugging answer choices back into the question to find which works
Starting from the answer and reversing steps to check if it matches the given information
Systematically checking each answer option by substitution
Begin with middle answer choice (C) since ACT answers are usually ordered
After testing one choice, eliminate answers that are too high or too low
Use when: answers are numbers, algebra is complex, or direct solution is unclear
Strategy of replacing variables with specific numbers to simplify a problem
Pick simple values that make calculation easy (often 1, 2, 10, or 100)
Substitute the same numbers into each answer choice to find which matches
Problems with expressions containing variables but no equation to solve
Use 100 as base value to make percent calculations easy
Use the same substituted values throughout the entire problem
Math problem presented in words/story form rather than equations
Converting words to mathematical expressions. "Sum"→+, "product"→×, "is"→=
Words indicating operations: total, difference, times, per, increased by, etc.
Let x represent the unknown quantity you want to find
Write mathematical relationship based on the problem description
Verify solution makes sense in context (positive distance, whole people, etc.)
Problems involving speed, work rate, or unit rates. Formula: distance = rate × time
Combining two or more items with different properties (concentrations, prices, etc.)
|x| < a means -a < x < a; |x| > a means x < -a or x > a
⌊x⌋ rounds down to nearest integer. ⌊3.7⌋ = 3
⌈x⌉ rounds up to nearest integer. ⌈3.2⌉ = 4
Function with different rules for different input ranges
Sum of arithmetic sequence. Formula: S = n(a₁+aₙ)/2
Sum of geometric sequence. Formula: S = a₁(1-rⁿ)/(1-r)
Σ symbol represents sum. ∑ᵢ₌₁ⁿ i means 1+2+3+...+n
Each term defined using previous term(s). Example: aₙ = aₙ₋₁ + 3
Measure of spread. How far values typically are from the mean. Symbol: σ
Square of standard deviation. σ² measures average squared distance from mean.
Values dividing data into four equal parts. Q1 (25%), Q2 (median), Q3 (75%)
IQR = Q3 - Q1. Middle 50% of data. Less affected by outliers.
Visual showing min, Q1, median, Q3, max of dataset
Bell-shaped curve. Most data near mean, symmetric spread
Relationship between two variables. Positive, negative, or no correlation.
Graph showing relationship between two variables as points
Has subject and predicate, expresses complete thought
Who or what the sentence is about
Tells what the subject does or is. Contains the verb.
Incomplete sentence missing subject, verb, or complete thought
Two or more independent clauses incorrectly joined
Can stand alone as complete sentence. Has subject + verb.
Cannot stand alone. Begins with subordinating word (because, when, if, etc.)
Error: two independent clauses joined only by comma
FANBOYS: for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so. Join independent clauses with comma.
Words like because, although, when, if that create dependent clauses
Word/phrase at start of sentence. Use comma after: "However, ..." "In the morning, ..."
Separate 3+ items: "apples, oranges, and bananas"
Two+ adjectives modifying same noun equally. Use comma between: "tall, dark stranger"
Extra info, not needed for meaning. Set off with commas: "My friend, who lives nearby, visited."
Necessary for meaning, NO commas: "Students who study hard succeed."
Noun phrase renaming another noun. Usually needs commas: "My dog, a beagle, barks loudly."
Two independent clauses joined by FANBOYS. Comma before conjunction: "I ran, and she walked."
Word/phrase interrupting sentence flow. Set off with commas: "The answer, in fact, is simple."
Joins related independent clauses: "I ran; she walked." Stronger than comma, weaker than period.
Introduces list, explanation, or quote. Must follow independent clause: "I need: milk, eggs, bread."
Shows ownership. Singular: add 's ("dog's"). Plural ending in s: add ' ("dogs'")
Shows missing letters: "don't" = "do not", "it's" = "it is"
Em dash (—) sets off interruptions or emphasis - stronger than comma
Enclose direct quotes. Periods/commas go inside: "Hello," she said.
Enclose extra info less important than commas would suggest: "The test (on Friday) was hard."
its = possessive ("its color"). it's = "it is" or "it has"
Singular subject takes singular verb, plural subject takes plural verb
Time of action: past, present, future. Keep consistent unless time changes.
Action happening now. He runs, she writes, they play.
Action already happened. He ran, she wrote, they played.
Doesn't follow -ed pattern. Examples: go/went, run/ran, write/wrote
Helps main verb. Examples: is, are, was, were, has, have, will, would, can, could
Don't shift tenses unnecessarily: "She runs and jumped" (wrong). "She ran and jumped" (correct).
Two+ subjects joined by "and" = plural verb. "Tom and Jerry run."
Word replacing noun: I, you, he, she, it, we, they, who, which, that
Noun that pronoun refers to. Pronoun must agree in number.
Singular antecedent → singular pronoun. Plural antecedent → plural pronoun.
Used as subject: I, you, he, she, it, we, they, who
Used as object: me, you, him, her, it, us, them, whom
Shows ownership: my, your, his, her, its, our, their (NO apostrophe!)
who = subject ("Who called?"). whom = object ("To whom did you speak?")
Unclear what noun it refers to: "John told Mike he was late." (Who was late?)
Word/phrase describing another word. Should be near word it modifies.
Modifier too far from word it modifies, causing confusion
Modifier with no clear word to modify. "Running fast, the finish line appeared." (Who was running?)
Modifier at start of sentence. Must be followed by word it modifies.
Modifies noun/pronoun. Answers which, what kind, how many.
Modifies verb, adjective, or adverb. Often ends in -ly.
Place modifier immediately next to what it describes
Using same grammatical form for items in a series or comparison
All items same form: "running, jumping, swimming" or "to run, to jump, to swim"
both...and, either...or, neither...nor, not only...but also - same form after each
Same structure on both sides of than/as: "better to give than to receive"
Mixing forms: "I like running, jumping, and to swim" (incorrect)
Keep same verb form throughout parallel structure
Noun, pronoun, verb, adjective, adverb, preposition, conjunction, interjection
Group of words with subject and verb. Independent or dependent.
Group of words without both subject and verb
Subject performs action: "John ate the cake."
Subject receives action: "The cake was eaten by John."
affect/effect, then/than, their/there/they're, your/you're, to/too/two
Avoid using two negatives: "don't have no" should be "don't have any"
Common expression with non-literal meaning. Must be learned, not figured out.
Correct preposition depends on context: "interested in", "familiar with", "different from"
Use "more/-er than" for comparing two. "Most/-est" for three or more.
Comparing two: add -er or use "more". Examples: taller, more beautiful
Comparing three+: add -est or use "most". Examples: tallest, most beautiful
Use fewest words to express idea clearly. Avoid wordiness.
Ideas should make sense and flow logically in context
Unnecessary repetition of ideas. "Free gift" (all gifts are free)
Using more words than necessary. "In order to" → "to"
Express ideas in fewest words while maintaining clarity
"past history", "future plans", "advance warning", "completely finish", "end result"
"due to the fact that" → "because", "at this point in time" → "now"
On ACT, often the shortest answer (DELETE or omit) is correct when avoiding redundancy
Selecting the right word for context, meaning, and tone
Emotional association of word. "Cheap" vs "affordable" vs "inexpensive"
Dictionary definition of word
Using specific, exact words rather than vague ones
Attitude conveyed through word choice: formal, informal, serious, playful
Surrounding words/sentences that hint at correct word choice
Word/phrase connecting ideas and showing relationship between sentences
Show difference: however, nevertheless, on the other hand, in contrast
Add information: furthermore, moreover, additionally, also, in addition
Show relationship: therefore, consequently, as a result, thus
Introduce examples: for instance, for example, specifically, namely
Show order: first, next, then, finally, meanwhile
Sum up: in conclusion, overall, ultimately, in summary
ACT question asking which option best achieves a specific goal
Carefully read what the question asks for before choosing
Cross out answers that don't achieve stated goal
Questions may ask for emphasizing certain idea or detail
May need to link previous sentence to next paragraph
Choose option matching essay's overall tone (formal, casual, etc.)
Determine if proposed sentence fits topic, adds value, and maintains flow
Remove if redundant, off-topic, or interrupts flow
Does information relate to paragraph's main idea?
Is information already stated elsewhere?
All sentences should support paragraph's main point
ACT format: choose yes/no, then choose reason that's true AND relevant
Sentences arranged so ideas flow smoothly and make sense
Events in time sequence: first, next, then, finally
State cause before describing effects
Introduce topic generally, then provide specific details
Pronoun must come AFTER its antecedent (noun it refers to)
Words like "however," "for example," "therefore" hint at logical placement
75 questions in 45 minutes. Tests grammar, punctuation, rhetoric, organization.
Questions embedded in 5 passages. Read, then answer questions in context.
No points deducted for wrong answers. Always guess if unsure!
About 36 seconds per question. Budget ~9 minutes per passage.
Usage/Mechanics (40 qs): grammar, punctuation. Rhetorical Skills (35 qs): strategy, organization.
Scored 1-36. Based only on number correct (raw score).
Engaging with text by asking questions, making predictions, noting key ideas
Central point or theme of passage. What the passage is mainly about.
Evidence, examples, facts that support the main idea
Reason for writing: inform, persuade, entertain, explain
Author's attitude toward subject: serious, humorous, critical, nostalgic, etc.
Conclusion based on evidence and reasoning, not directly stated
Surrounding words/sentences that help determine meaning of unfamiliar word
Cross out wrong answers to narrow choices. Eliminate obviously incorrect first.
Specific words/sentences from passage supporting answer. Can you point to it?
Words like "always," "never," "all," "none" - usually make answer wrong (too absolute)
Looks right but wrong. May use passage words but misstate relationship.
On ACT, choose BEST answer, not just one that "could" work
Correct answers supported by passage text, not outside knowledge
Prose Fiction, Social Science, Humanities, Natural Science - 10 questions each
Do passages in ANY order. Start with your strongest passage type.
35 minutes for 4 passages = about 8-9 minutes per passage
Light read for main idea, then refer back for questions (don't memorize!)
Some prefer reading questions before passage to know what to look for
Note introduction, body paragraphs, conclusion - helps locate info
Managing time to complete all questions. Don't spend too long on one question.
Total time for ACT Reading section. 40 questions.
If stuck, skip question and return if time permits
No points off for wrong answers - always fill in an answer!
Time yourself during practice to build speed and accuracy
Answer quick questions first, save harder ones for later

Begin with middle answer choice (C) since ACT answers are usually ordered
After testing one choice, eliminate answers that are too high or too low
Use when: answers are numbers, algebra is complex, or direct solution is unclear
Another name for number substitution - choosing specific values for variables to make problems easier to solve
A Pythagorean triple: a² + b² = c² where (3, 4, 5) satisfies 3² + 4² = 5² (9 + 16 = 25). Commonly scaled to 6-8-10, 9-12-15, etc.
A Pythagorean triple: 5² + 12² = 13² (25 + 144 = 169). Useful for quickly finding hypotenuse without calculation.
A Pythagorean triple: 7² + 24² = 25² (49 + 576 = 625). Less common but appears on ACT.
A Pythagorean triple: 8² + 15² = 17² (64 + 225 = 289). Another right triangle shortcut.
The distance along a curved arc. Formula: arc length = (θ/360) × 2πr, where θ is the central angle in degrees.
The amount of space inside a 2D shape, measured in square units (in², ft², cm²).
Exponents written as fractions. x^(m/n) = ⁿ√(x^m). For example, 8^(2/3) = ∛(8²) = ∛64 = 4.
Lines that never intersect and have the same slope. If line 1 has slope m, line 2 parallel to it also has slope m.
Lines that intersect at 90°. Their slopes are negative reciprocals: if line 1 has slope m, line 2 perpendicular to it has slope -1/m.
For right triangles: a² + b² = c², where a and b are legs and c is the hypotenuse. Used to find missing side lengths.
The steepness and direction of a line. Formula: m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁) = rise/run.
The amount of 3D space inside a solid object, measured in cubic units (in³, ft³, cm³).
Portions of a circle's circumference. Measured by their central angle or by arc length.
A shared denominator when adding/subtracting fractions. Find by listing multiples or using LCM.
A technique to rewrite x² + bx as a perfect square: add (b/2)² to both sides to get (x + b/2)².
Simplifying fractions before multiplying by canceling common factors in numerators and denominators.
Oval-shaped curves with equation x²/a² + y²/b² = 1. Both terms are positive with different denominators.
Circle equation: x² + y² + Dx + Ey + F = 0. Requires completing the square to find center and radius.
Two-branched curves with equation x²/a² - y²/b² = 1 or y²/a² - x²/b² = 1. Opposite signs distinguish from ellipses.

term: isolate it on one side of the equation
definition: Move all terms with the variable to one side and all constants to the other, using inverse operations.
A 45-45-90 triangle. If each leg = a, then hypotenuse = a√2. Ratio is 1 : 1 : √2.
The smallest common denominator for adding/subtracting fractions. Equals the LCM of the denominators.
Equations that graph as straight lines. Standard form: Ax + By = C. Slope-intercept form: y = mx + b.
Straight paths extending infinitely in both directions. Defined by slope and y-intercept.
To divide fractions, flip the second fraction and multiply. a/b ÷ c/d = a/b × d/c.
Numbers less than zero. Rules: negative × negative = positive, negative × positive = negative.
PEMDAS: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division (left to right), Addition/Subtraction (left to right).
Pizza-slice regions of circles bounded by two radii and an arc. Area = (θ/360) × πr².
3-sided polygons. Sum of angles = 180°. Area = ½ × base × height. Types: right, isosceles, equilateral.
The amount of 3D space inside an object, measured in cubic units (in³, ft³, m³).
A perfectly round 2D shape where every point on the edge is the same distance from the center. Area = πr², Circumference = 2πr.
A 3-sided polygon. Sum of angles = 180°. Area = ½ × base × height. Types include right, isosceles, and equilateral.
A 4-sided shape with 4 right angles. Opposite sides are equal. Area = length × width, Perimeter = 2(length + width).
A 4-sided shape with exactly one pair of parallel sides. Area = ½(base₁ + base₂) × height.
A 3D box shape with 6 rectangular faces. Volume = length × width × height, Surface Area = 2(lw + lh + wh).
A 3D shape with circular ends and straight sides. Volume = πr²h, Surface Area = 2πr² + 2πrh.
A perfectly round 3D object. Volume = (4/3)πr³, Surface Area = 4πr².
A 3D shape with a circular base tapering to a point. Volume = (1/3)πr²h, Surface Area = πr² + πrl (l = slant height).
A line that rises from left to right (m > 0). As x increases, y increases.
A line that falls from left to right (m < 0). As x increases, y decreases.
A horizontal line (m = 0). No change in y as x changes. Equation: y = constant.
A vertical line. No change in x as y changes. Division by zero in slope formula. Equation: x = constant.
Fundamental mathematical abilities including solving equations, simplifying expressions, working with variables, and manipulating formulas. These form the foundation for most ACT Math questions.
Numbers that represent parts of a whole, written as a ratio of two integers (numerator/denominator). Essential for solving problems involving division, ratios, percentages, and proportions.
A notation that indicates how many times to multiply a number (the base) by itself. For example, 3⁴ means 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 = 81. The small raised number is the exponent or power.

The inverse operation of exponents. The square root (√) asks "what number times itself equals this?" The cube root (∛) asks "what number times itself three times equals this?" Written as √x or x^(1/2).
The inverse operation of exponentiation. A logarithm answers the question: "To what power must we raise the base to get this number?" For example, log₂(8) = 3 because 2³ = 8.
The inverse operation of exponentiation. Written as logₐ(x) = y, meaning "a raised to what power equals x?" Answer: y. For example, log₂(8) = 3 because 2³ = 8.

An operation that reverses the effect of another operation. For example, subtraction is the inverse of addition, division is the inverse of multiplication, and logarithms are the inverse of exponentiation.

In logarithms (logₐ(x)), the base is "a" - the number being raised to a power. In exponents (aⁿ), the base is "a" - the number being multiplied by itself. Common bases: 10 (common log), e (natural log), 2 (binary).

In logarithms logₐ(x), the argument is "x" - the number you're taking the logarithm of. The argument must always be positive (x > 0) because you can't raise a positive base to any power and get a negative or zero result.
The output or answer to a mathematical operation. In logₐ(x) = y, the result is y. In 2³ = 8, the result is 8.
A notation that indicates how many times to multiply a number (the base) by itself. For example, 3⁴ means 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 = 81. In logarithms, the exponent is what you're solving for.
A logarithm with base 10, written as log(x) or log₁₀(x). For example, log(100) = 2 because 10² = 100. Common logs are useful for scientific notation and orders of magnitude.
Euler's number, approximately 2.71828... A fundamental mathematical constant that appears in exponential growth, compound interest, and calculus. The base of the natural logarithm.

A logarithm with base e (Euler's number ≈ 2.718), written as ln(x) or logₑ(x). For example, ln(e²) = 2. Natural logs appear frequently in exponential growth/decay, compound interest, and higher mathematics.
A formula to convert logarithms between different bases: logₐ(x) = log(x)/log(a) or ln(x)/ln(a). Useful when your calculator only has log and ln buttons but you need a different base.

Mathematical statements that compare two expressions using symbols: < (less than), > (greater than), ≤ (less than or equal to), ≥ (greater than or equal to). Unlike equations, inequalities have a range of solutions.
A mathematical statement comparing two expressions with <, >, ≤, or ≥. For example, x > 5 means "x is greater than 5." Solutions include all values that make the inequality true.
The set of all values that satisfy an inequality. For example, x > 3 has solutions {3.1, 4, 5, 100, ...}. Often represented on a number line or in interval notation.
Two or more inequalities combined with "and" or "or." Example: 2 < x < 5 means "x is greater than 2 AND less than 5." Example: x < 1 OR x > 3 means x is in one range or the other.

Two or more inequalities that must all be satisfied simultaneously. Graphically represented as the overlapping shaded region where all inequalities are true. Common in linear programming and optimization.
In systems of inequalities, the area on a graph where all inequalities are satisfied simultaneously. This region represents all coordinate pairs (x, y) that make every inequality in the system true.
The distance of a number from zero on the number line, always positive or zero. Written as |x|. For example, |5| = 5 and |-5| = 5 because both are 5 units from zero.
The distance of a number from zero, always non-negative. Denoted |x|. Examples: |3| = 3, |-7| = 7, |0| = 0. Geometrically represents distance, which cannot be negative.
How far a number is from 0 on the number line. Always measured as a positive value (or zero). This is exactly what absolute value represents: |x| = distance from x to 0.
The characteristic shape of an absolute value function y = |x|. The graph forms a "V" with the vertex at the origin (0,0), opening upward. The left side has slope -1, the right side has slope +1.
Mathematical operations that are the inverse of exponentiation. A logarithm answers: "To what power must the base be raised to get this number?" For example, log₂(8) = 3 because 2³ = 8.
Logarithms with base 10, written as log(x) or log₁₀(x). For example, log(100) = 2 because 10² = 100. Your calculator has a LOG button for these.
Logarithms with base e (Euler's number ≈ 2.718), written as ln(x). For example, ln(e²) = 2. Your calculator has an LN button for these. Commonly used in exponential growth/decay.
Mathematical statements that compare two expressions using <, >, ≤, or ≥. Unlike equations which have specific solutions, inequalities have a range of solutions.
